content.description: This is the farthest left of the french lines before getting into the much shorter lines and descent routes. A bit of a trap unroped. It looks and starts easy like the 'steps' lines on the path-facing side and flag side, but a single side-pull near the top may be difficult to reverse.
content.location: The "Steps" line left center of the northern side of the block.

content.description: ACB. The main line visible from a southern approach between the Russian flag and the arete. (Some chumbalone took the liberty of painting the first 7 holds yellow, but thankfully left the puzzle of the top out crux for us to work out on our own ).To the right of the 4th jug, you'll pass an almost reclaimed RURP that still holds a bounce test (2020). When the paint runs out, it is all side pulls leaning left but avoid the temptation to exit or end it there there (5.7+) as the crux is getting under and then topping out at the twin tree. The crux is in the final moves, topping out as opposed to ringing the bell (might bring up to 5.9)
content.location: Under the twin trees at the edge, left of the russian flag

content.description: Another diagonal line between the flags on the south side of the block
content.location: A series of steps between the nordic and russian flags.

content.description: A diagonal line up the path-facing side of the block from the eye of Horus to the highest point.
content.protection: For the sake of speed, I prefer a 50' span of webbing to the big trees but plenty of security available if bringing rope.
content.location: Start left, move up and right to finish at the highest point. Variations for a direct start and exit left available.

content.description: Crux is low ending on very confident holds
content.protection: Crux is low ending on very confident holds
content.location: The is the obvious corner separating the path-facing French Steps side of the block and the Norway to Russia canvas.

content.description: This is a jug haul if you hit the right horizontals
content.location: The crack punctuated by ladder-rung horizontals ending with a tree in the top of the crack

content.description: While a tempting exit is to span the arete from a few feet up the Bulgarian, this easy line burns through its hardest moves getting off the ground and becomes a ladder from there. Be cautious with the top 2 blocks. This is a good lesson in using smaller holds on good rock as opposed to ape hanging a big hold on potentially loose rock.
content.protection: Half rack. Very short and an easy top rope to set up. Has probably already gone as a boulder.
content.location: Start in the very obvious nook, under the small pointed roof left of the arete on the Bulgarian.

content.description: A learning opportunity for making use of anything available. The crux for for a guest is keeping an open mind and open eyes and using the wall of the right wing, the face of the pillar, etc (not obsessing about the crack simply because it is there).
content.protection: Easy to set up from above, can also be protected ground up
content.location: North side of the block moving away from the path before the shorter boulder problems

content.description: On the Warren County Bikeway between the outlets in Queensbury and Lake George Village is a notorious graffiti block with a surprising amount of opportunity.  Steep but easy territory with low cruxes and a height of ~24 feet make for an exciting boulder, while easy access to the top afford top-rope opportunity to introduce a variety of terrain.  This may be the best early morning or sunset run for a quick fix to touch stone in the southernmost reaches of Lake George.  Please don't take access for granted as our comrades have already given us a black eye (by painting all the holds of the Russian RURP line yellow for example). Please do not become a complaint for the cyclists.
